name: Gottfried Kibelka
text: The short hike up from the blue trail will get your heart pumping. The rock on top of the hill is a little difficult to climb and probably not the safest adventure for small children. The view is not as spectacular as King's Chair or other Vista points on Oak Mountain but it is more entertaining to walk over the hill than following almost level blue trail around that hill.

name: Chase
text: Not the best view in the summer because of all the foliage, but a nice hike.

name: Zac Robison
text: Good hiking trial but there wasn't much of a view.

name: Jacob
text: Very steep hike up to a large rock... From the top of the rock it’s a pretty view.

name: Lloyd-Janet Mize
text: Higher trail

text: Higher trail

name: Krystal Bentley-Moore
text: I absolutely loooove this place!! It’s about a 30 minute hike mostly easy however once you make it almos tto the fall you have to scale down a couple hard areas….. overall an amazing hike and experience!!

name: Preston Marshall
text: Great falls, terrible parking. Do not park at the trailhead under any circumstances. Go down the road a piece, make your first right onto County Road 3025 and go all the way down the gravel road. There are some nice folks that will let you park and access the trail via their property. There’s also a suggested donation mailbox. For exact location see the AllTrails reviews for Caney Creek.

name: Tony Craig
text: Fanning Trail - decent challenge of a trail at times - moderate at best - well marked and ample parking. Good options for easier trail loop via Jones Valley Loop & Stevenson Trail.

name: Ellen George
text:
Just an FYI the parking lot is behind a church. When we first arrived at the destination, we were confused and thought Google had taken us to the wrong place, but it is indeed a hiking trailhead. Just drive behind the church and you will see a sign with the trail mappings.

Beautiful little hiking spot with a nice little stream. Not too busy but the trails are a bit messy/chaotic and it is hard to make sure you are still on the path. For that reason I did remove a star. Overall still a very nice area though. The waterfall was very small when i visited, despite it being spring so do keep in mind that it is highly seasonal.

name: 高村政克
text:
(Translated by Google) It is a spot that you can enjoy only now that the corona is bad.
I am visiting to relieve my daily stress and lack of exercise.

(Original)
コロナ禍の今だからこそ楽しめるスポットです。
日頃の溜まったストレスと運動不足解消に訪れています。

name: Michael Noerr
text: I sincerely dislike this hill.  Had a good friend of mine that i used to go riding with and he always wanted to start by going up this hill.  That said, if you like riding, this really is a great place to start.  You get to the top and everything is "downhill from there."  This trail also has some really picturesque views.

name: Gary Holt
text: Very enjoyable trail, shady all the way, a few areas that were just a little challenging. The route we took was Oak Park trail then turn on the second buzzard's roost trail then turn onto Dallas trail, follow that to Bankhead, then back to Oak Park. Always take a picture of the map at the beginning of the trail and study it. This place is one of my favorite trails.

name: Cristy Cowan
text: We put in our kayaks and Spent most of the day just enjoying the view. The water was calm and it was a peaceful day. Can't wait to go back.

name: Thomas Overall
text: Very nice place. Beautiful trails easygoing to hard climbing alongside the damn. Very good place to fish. Boat ramps all around the lake. MT bikes are welcome and just too much fun

name: Dewey B
text:
Nice, peaceful, well maintained trail, for the couple of miles that I hiked, with a couple of brand new foot bridges over creeks that feed into the reservoir.

The trail goes around the Duck River reservoir, so you can always see the water during your hike.

You also can park at the boat ramp and easily put your kayak or canoe in and paddle around the trail from the water. The mile marker signs are both on the trail and on the water's edge. Great idea. There needs to be a trash pickup day on the lake though, tons of trash floating along the shores.

name: Christena Hasenbein
text: Very long trail! Bring lots of water! Had a great time!

name: Jack Dixon
text: This trail is gorgeous. It has just the right amount of shading and breeze to make hiking it pleasant. The trail is pretty flat so it's an easy trail to traverse and not too physically intensive. I enjoyed every minute of my 2 and a half hour hike out here.

name: William Jessip
text: Boat launch is temporary closed due to work at dam.

name: Sloane Thompson
text: Beautiful and clear path! New bridges on the pathway. My new favorite trail head for duck river

name: Alex Pajao
text: Absolutely gorgeous. I really appreciate how people care for the area and take responsibility for the trash and clutter in the area. I brought a trash bag with me to pick up any litter I found and was surprised to only fill half the bag.

name: Zac Burks
text: Great simple hike with beautiful views

name: BIG MAC
text: Our first time to enjoy this wonderful place but certainly not the last

name: Glenn Lindsey
text: Clean an calm an nice trails an lake

name: Hugh Benefield
text: Take a moment to pull up GPS and find the roads that once ran through the Duck River. It's ominous but starkly beautiful to see a paved road disappear underneath Cullman's water source.

name: Hope Reed
text: Beautiful ❤️❤️❤️ can't wait to try the fishing

name: Shannon Creel
text: Enjoy some good ol fishing

name: David L Casteel (MonkC)
text: Nice Trail not finished take me a bug spray moderate Trail

name: Maria Landers
text: The trails are awesome!

name: Lane Pair
text: Great place to walk and fish!!

name: Paul Haines
text: Great place with easy access to the water and trails

name: Gregory Hickok
text: Great place to hike or fish!

name: KAREN RALEY
text: Great place to canoe..

name: JP Slee
text: Beautiful trail, well maintained, relatively easy

name: Shalon Thomas
text: Awesome place to relax

name: Clefargle Smash
text: Great fishing for crappie

name: william riddle
text: Loved it.

name: Shannon Dees
text: Love it

name: Todd Drummer
text: Kayaking.

name: Clint SouthEasternGeo
text:
Do not follow Google maps suggestions and hope to find a trail here. The trail head is the Dollar General parking lot…
The Alabama 21 trail head is part of the larger pan hoodie trail system, which walks along the roadways, dirt roads to connect you to mountain tops etc. New line the pan hoodie trail is fantastic, the Alabama 21 trail head is a Dollar General

name: lindajoy Daugherty
text: If u love nature and being in GOD'S  beautiful  land then this is the place. Very peaceful. Tin roof on building was a job  I  helped with. Shining and new.

name: Anne Smith
text: Amazing

name: Donna Bollenbach
text:
While camping in Desoto State Park (May 2021), we made a trip to the Desoto Falls. As we heard it was busy on the weekends, we chose Tuesday to go to avoid the crowds. The picnic area at the top of the Falls does not open until 9 am, so we decided to hike the Desoto Falls Overlook Trail located outside the park first. The short, but rocky trail to the overlook was well worth the effort. At the end of the trail was a small rock outcrop that formed a smooth platform, just barely big enough for two adults to stand side by side. From this rock, you can view Desoto Falls from above. The Falls sit nearly center in a bowl of jagged rock cliffs and drop 104 feet into a large lake in the canyon below. The view was humbling.

After our hike on the overlook trail, we headed to the Desoto Falls picnic area to view the falls from the top. The picnic area has three levels to view the falls: From the top, looking over the dam, is the historic, but now defunct, A.A. Miller Dam built in 1925 for the first hydroelectric power in Alabama. Above the dam is a lake where visitors can swim, kayak, and canoe.

There is a set of concrete steps leading down from the top to the middle overlook. Each step is decorated in colorful reflective tiles, some spelling words of a famous naturalist, John Muir, a reminder that “Everybody needs beauty as well as bread, places to play in and pray in, where nature may heal and give strength to body and soul.” In the middle  are a series of broad falls whee the water pools and channels before its final descent. Follow the path around the rocks and down to the lower overlook where you can see a ribbon-like side view of the 104-foot drop of the falls into the canyon. There is a trail that takes you to the bottom of the falls, but we did not do it this trip.

name: J R
text: The hike to the bottom of the falls was not difficult and very diverse. We took the pink and white path and found a cool cave. Wish we had brought tubes for floating in the basin. Would love to come back sometime.

name: Sybille Moore
text: Well marked with pink paint. Lots of roots, but overall easy trail to base of falls. This point takes you right to the parking area off the main road.

name: Sandy Koivu
text: A little rough getting to the end but way worth the trip

name: Thomas Brittain
text: Use this trail to get to the bottom of the falls. It is a 1.4 mile round trip, pretty easy hike and a very clearly marked trail. Just park on the beaten down dirt that is just off the road. Plenty of parking spots. This is really the best way to see DeSoto Falls

name: John Mittell
text: We took the pink trail down and the pink/white trail back up.  I believe this is the easier way.  The trip took 2 hrs, including a lunch break.  Beautiful view of the falls.

name: Mary McGuire Smith
text: The new parking lot is nice, the trails are well-marked and newly maintained, and the view of the falls from the opposite rim is great for photos.

name: Rosie Rene Parrish
text: Beautiful view at the end. Trail was great. Easy to navigate well maintained trail.

name: John Hall
text: Enjoyed the trail and waterfall at the end.

name: Holly Harpe
text: Loved it. Found the cave. The view of the falls is best at the basin.

name: Dusty Smith
text: Had a great little hike beautiful river

name: Payton H. Stantis
text: This is easily one of my favorite trails in the state. It's an easy hike down, but a bit strenuous going up. We have a lot of luck finding chanterelles here!

name: Boss Man
text: This trail, like many of the other trails in the LRC National Preserve, is just absolutely beautiful. The photos from my budget LG phone don't do the canyon floor and the trail much justice. It is rocky and it does cross a small stream in a couple of places. If there has been a lot of rainfall, be mindful of that. Of course, it is a steep hike with a few switchbacks that lead down to the river. It is slightly less strenuous than Eberhart, but still a challenging hike back up.

name: Jay C
text: A great hike, but steep climb back to the top. But worth it.

name: Ashley Deering
text: Fun trail! Very steep and rocky, but beautiful opening to the river at the bottom.

name: Cecily Caudle
text: Nice level trail, great skyline views, not much variance.

name: Asif Rony
text: Superb view

name: Northern Steeleiii
text: This trail is my serenity prayer place where I come to talk to the Lord and de stress myself from my daily problems.

name: Pamela Sparks
text: A shaded running trail!!! I love the inclines and cleanliness of the trail. Great parking and scenery.

name: JEFFERY THOMPSON
text: i love this trail. GREAT views, well maintained.

name: Steven Young
text: Trail was lengthened

name: J. Miller
text: We parked at this crossing on a weekday morning and hiked a total of 5 miles without meeting a single other person. It's a gorgeous stretch of trail. Big thank-you to the trail stewards who had recently trimmed the vegetation next to the trail so the walking was easy.

name: Andrew Stevens
text: Room to park 3-4 cars on side of road.

name: Al W.
text:
glug glug gliug glug

i almost drownd

name: Jon Elmore
text: Well kept trail with services spaced well for water refill and bathrooms. Great views on the Upper and Lower trails south of the dam.

name: Colleen Dixon
text: This was a fantastic trail, easy, but hilly enough to be interesting, pretty views, cows nearby and creeks to cross. We did miles 4.5 to 3 and back.

name: David Imm
text: Duck River is an awesome place to mountain bike. But be prepared to get off your bike and be smart. If you try to ride over all the rocks he'll end up taking your bike to the repair place.

name: John Hicks
text: Great walking/biking trail! Need bug spray,  but beautiful trail!

name: a baker
text: The trail was well marked and great for walking, but the sludge and garbage in the water was disgusting and smelled horrible.  The buzzing power lines in part of the trail sounded like a waterfall inspiring us to walk further.  The map online led us to a small parking space and we saw no signage on 278 for the recreation area.  Very disappointing

name: StressDaddy
text: Trail is very shady so no matter what the temperature is it seems to be a relatively cool place to hike bugs aren't bad lots of good fishing as well the trail is wonderful my five year old and I have a great time

name: Local 360
text: Excellent hiking, & mountain bike trails here. Good for fishing too.

name: Michael Winston
text: Great trail for the family. We take our 4 year old daughter with us and she LOVES the trail. “Mommy, daddy I want to go hiking!”

name: Page Sparks
text: Even with the weather it was a really good trail. Very low traffic and some good resting spots. I was told to watch out for dead fish and armadillos, but that must have been down by the water, because we didn't see anything.

name: Stacy Nix
text: Great place to take your family or just go for some peace of mind

name: Mandy Handley
text: Definitely more of a Biker Trail than a Hiker one. It's pretty straight forward. Not a lot of views of nature. Still, it is a nice place to go for exercise. I am a photographer and captured a couple of shots of the water, but that's about it. I will also say, it is better after the rains, to experience the little Brookes that go through the trail along the way.

name: Scott Barber
text: It was a beautiful place and I loved the trails and it was a great pleasure visiting.

name: Amy Moon
text: Its was great! but, there was alot of bug bites.

name: bev bauer
text: Welcoming trail sharing mountain bikers. Great views easy trail.

name: Ben Young
text: Great mtb!

name: palacepainter2
text: Lovely place to take the family.

name: Princess Lacey
text: Amazing view

name: Chels Bells
text: Very beautiful and well maintained trails.

name: Thomas Overall
text: Mountain biking was great. Had over 20 miles of good trails

name: Lenette Wisener
text: The trails are nice and vary in incline . Starting to  grow up some though. Just waiting for FISHING!

name: Steve West
text:
I have enjoyed it since before the reservoir was filled with water. It is intermediate difficulty (nothing too strenuous) with beautiful lake scenery, plenty of rocks and streams, and a nice view of the new dam. As of 9/2017, they have finished about 3/4 of what will be a 26 mile loop. There are 4 ways to access it. Starting from the Cullman end of the trail and moving to the Holly Pond end of the trail,

1. On Hwy 69 in Fairview, go west toward Cullman past Fairview town limits. Turn left (south) on Co Rd 1534 (on the western edge of the white fences at Haynes farm.) Then turn right on Co Rd 1656. Bear left and drive 2 miles. Turn left on Co Rd 1651. In 1 mile, it dead ends at one end of the trail (as of 9/17). This is being developed as a boat ramp entrance.

2. On Hwy 69 in Fairview, drive west toward Cullman to the second yellow light at Fairview town limits. Turn left (south) on County Road 1662 (at  sign for Antioch Missionary Baptist). Go 1.5 miles, dog leg Left-Right at Antioch Church. You are now on Co. Rd. 1660, and it dead ends in 2 miles. Park and it's a short walk down the hill and through the wooden gate. This is less than 2 miles from the end of the trail above (as of 9/2017).

3. From Holly Pond, head west on Hwy 278. Pass the white fences on the right with the sign to the cowboy church at the edge of the fence. Take a right Co Rd 1651 (not the road with the small junk yard, the next road opposite a sign for Duck River Baptist). When the road widens, you will come to the new handicapped accessible pier on the left. Park and this is the other end of the trail (as of 9/2017).

4. Follow directions #3 from Holly Pond but keep  going past the pier. A couple of miles farther, the road will end at the main trailhead. This is lessc than 4 miles from the end of the trail (as of 9/2017).

name: David L Casteel (MonkC)
text: Nice Trail not completely finished carry bug spray moderate Trail

name: Chris Redden
text: Hikeing and plenty of fishing

name: Lexilou Faith
text: So much fun fishing!

name: T Tunes
text: Beautiful hike or biking trail and dog-friendly!

name: Kenny Haynes
text: Excellent place to hike.

name: Gary Harper
text: New trail on lake , good views.

name: Amy Hall
text: Great trail beautiful river views

name: Allen Summers
text: Rough roads to and from the boat ramps.

name: Chuck Smith
text: Good place for short hikes

name: Sherri Pope
text: Great hiking!

name: BROOKE TYLER
text: It is 20 miles

name: Najlaa Jaleesah
text: The view is amazing but its unpaved road for 2-3 mile 👎🏾

name: Beth T
text: Hit the trail and go across the dam to the spillway. Nice place. Relaxing. Well worth it. Short hike.

name: Craig Ainsworth
text: Beautiful spillway over over the dam, and nice area to have a hike or just relax

name: David Littlefield
text: Trail is a little challenging. Be safe as it is on the edge of a cliff.

name: john vick
text: Beautiful area and great hiking trail

name: RJ
text: Great quiet place

name: Harnessing Your Divine Feminine Andrea
text: Always lovely

name: Sean Lyle
text: Really nice hike

name: Pearl D
text: Great hiking trail in Talladega Ntl Forest.

name: Art Of Valor
text: Great place to meditate, chill, relax and observe some of the most beautiful scenery the state of Alabama and the South has to offer. The city of Piedmont is nearby. One of America's hidden gems in my opinion. Love going here on a bad day and listening to nature speak. This place makes a good day even better. If you're in the Piedmont, Alabama area, you don't want to miss out on this wonderful place!

name: Nikki Palmer
text: Great meditation center! After about 1 minute of the breathing technique I was mind blown at the instant results, I recommend the Wim Hof method to everyone it only takes 10 minutes and its results you can feel. The mountains were great also!!💖 the best part is its all free!!!

name: Sean Lyle
text: Always a good place to be

name: adam dasinger
text: 2nd highest mountain in the State of Alabama. The drive up FS 500 is worth your time.

name: Buddha Bishop
text: Great place to camp and getaway from it all

name: Jason Jackson
text: Beautiful rugged wild

name: Wanda M.
text: Love the mountains

name: Dustin Walker
text: Beautiful place

name: K. Miller
text: Beautiful hike, easy enough for the kids.

name: Craig Priestley
text: Wildflower Trail and Fagan Springs are perhaps my favorite trails in Huntsville. The flowing creek which originates from Fagan's Spring accompanies you the entire trek with beautiful deep pools and sheer rock bottom shallows. There are large 5ft + drops in the creek bed if you explore far enough up the stream beyond the point where Fagan's Spring connects with the main creek. Though dry every time I've seen these falls, they are excellent to climb and view. And of course you can connect to other extensive trails connected to these via the Monte Sano system. These trails are a must-see.

name: Richard Johnson
text: very good place for memories

name: julia kay
text: Stella & I have been on many hikes this year & this was one of our favorits. I loved the way the trail followed the little creek most of the way & the water was very clear. This gave Stella a chance to drink & cool off. The trails were very worn, wide, & easy to follow. They were well marked too. The view from the top was very beautiful. We can't wait to go back

name: Tac
text: Great trail, truly rated at moderate, scramble, creek crossings, muddy, hard climbs at times. Decent view at the small overlook area. Came in at 5 miles for me on my app. Enjoy.

name: Jason Hart
text: Awesome Father's day hiking experience with my daughters last year.  Thanks for the great job of designing and maintenance of the trails.

name: William Lock
text: I fell in love with the views form the peak. I was glad to sit and enjoy every moment. It is quite only wind and birds to listen to.  Yes take it all in.

name: mark deguenther
text:
Gorgeous hike! Tremendous variety... walk along the river, turn inland thru boggy bottom lands full of ferns, head uphill thru long leaf pine forests, summit with rock outcroppings, hardwood forests on the return with a finish down steep switchbacks.
Lots of wildflowers in bloom now.
4.7 mile loop seemed much shorter.

name: Denny Brenny (Dom)
text: A real nice 4.7 mile loop hike. Relative easy trail with a little elevation. Trail is well maintained.

name: David Williams
text: This is my go to trail. Close to home and not crowded.

name: Karen Hilgartner
text: Beautiful hike with varying terrain, streamside walks, and lovely Mountain views.

name: Michael Cannon
text: Absolutely beautiful levels for just about anyone. Clean well marked outdoor Alabama at its best

name: Christina Smith
text: Took us about 5 and a half hours to hike the whole loop and up to saddle rock.  But it was a great hike

name: Dari Roden
text: Beautiful trail with a section of old growth trees. Also, access to river to fish or kayak.

name: Jennifer Jenkins
text: So clean and so beautiful!

name: Brad Keller
text: Fantastic place to hike.

name: Alan Thompson
text: Wonderful hiking experience!

name: Jonathan Welsh
text: Pretty cool place. There are a few ponds on this trail which is nice. This trail is perfectly marked, very easy to stay on it. Its a nice walk. Would recommend.

name: Kimm Wright
text: BEAUTIFUL!!!

name: ReelDistractionAction
text: This place was great. The trail is well maintained,  and there are several campsites and places to stop along the trail to soak in nature.

name: Tim Moore
text: Beautiful scenery along the trail following Thompson Creek.

name: John Cork
text: Trail 206 is basically a deer trail. Expect to get lost and carry a compass. I got lost over and over until I got a few miles down. I did the loop that came back on 208. It took me 9 hours but I would recommend it being a two day hike. Had a ton of fun but I would like to see more trail markers.

name: Michael Turner
text: Excellent adventure through the woods. Moderate hills and a few spots of mud. Wear hiking attire. Dont forget the bug spray. We walked the yellow trail, 1.5 miles round-trip. Stopped halfway through for lunch( we brought it of course). The welcome center does have a small selection of snacks, drinks, and pre-packaged sandwiches. There is a cave tour that is offered for a price. Trails are free.

name: Justine Woodham
text: Beautiful place.  We walked the caverns.  Didn't have time to experience the trails in this trip.

name: Brian Patsos
text: Great place, went for the cave run

name: Atticus Grim
text: Very scenic place and cool trails however not marked very well

name: Robert Talley
text: A great place to go hiking either by yourself or with a group of people. $5 per person to enter. They have trails with varying degrees of difficulty. I saw many people walking and hiking but I also saw a good number of people mountain biking. I went in the fall before the leaves fell and it was difficult to see out on the horizon but the view under the tree canopy was still worth it. There are rock shelves and look out points.

name: Diana
text: a beautiful park with great trails for walking, biking, running.

name: Nour Salam
text: Amazing for birdwatching

name: Laura Clingman
text: I went to Monte Sano State Park to take the Stone Cuts Trail. The stone cuts are very cool, definitely worth the hike! But be prepared that the trail is steep in many places and you need to be aware of all the rocks and roots. But it's worth the about 3 Mile hike round trip.

name: Madan Nagaraju
text: Number of fantastic trails around, Monte Sano in general is a great place to drive, hike, camp or just be in the park.

name: Robert Dornbos
text: Lots of good trails to hike in the park. Saw 6 deer (fleetingly) while hiking Keith and Goat trails today. Fallen leaves almost obscure parts of the lower trails. Beautiful day to be out there.

name: Jerry Pierce
text: This mountain has several different Trail that are several different miles they also has a picnic area that you can book and have parties wedding birthdays whatever you like.

name: Bernhard Vogler
text: Great hike

name: zach smithson
text: I usually like parking at the park, but this is a nice park when I'm doing firetower trail

name: James Davis
text: Great places to hike.

name: Fritz LaFitts
text: Beautiful

name: Asim Gilani
text: A great place

name: DIPYO Much
text: Clean and relaxing

name: Bobbie Pigg
text: Nice trails

name: Edgar Schroeder
text:
(Translated by Google) Very nice and shady forest paths. A nice advice in the park office and a very friendly park supervision. Thank you, everything is perfect 👍

(Original)
Sehr schöne und schattige Waldwege. Eine nette Beratung im Park Office und eine sehr freundlicher Parkaufsicht. Danke, alles perfekt 👍

name: Roland Howard
text: Very short walk.  Trail requires good balance and level of health.  Falls are beautiful and soothing emotionally!  Highly recommend this place!

name: Sharon Kilzer
text: Pretty cool place to camp.

name: Kara-PJ Henry
text: Beautiful hike.  Three more waterfalls around the loop as well.

name: B Taylor
text: Great place to visit and hike around. Several falls close by. Not a marked/official trail but  easy to access.

name: Bree k
text:
Great time and love the wildlife. Hard to park and get in, but once ya do, it's worth the time it takes.
I also noticed the lack of trash and that is really awesome.
Keep up the good work in the community with this trail.
Thanks for having it available for those of us that still enjoy the planet we are actually on🚀👍🏻

name: Jeremy West
text: Best regards to your family

name: Luke
text: Decent trail nicely kept up pretty short though

name: Scott Mitchell
text: I have Been walking running and riding this trail for 20 plus years ..quite peaceful and very manageable for all connects my neighborhood with my parents neighborhood

name: Reed Barrett
text: Very tucked away and hidden. I love the privacy of this place as nobody else seems to know about it not even the people in the surrounding neighborhoods. there are not very many Lookout points however if you Veer off the trail there  are many cool Cliffs and caves

name: Rawdog
text: Great cars and service very involved in community.

name: Bob Stell
text: Nice nbhood walk. Easy going

name: Cindy Coffey
text: Very gorgeous views with GREAT hiking trails!

name: Natalie Corson
text: Quaint

name: Satya Grandhi
text: Nice little trail, 0.5 miles long.  Free parking on site. Wild flower bloom during Fall /Spring seasons provide good opportunity for pictures.

name: Theodore Swift
text: Adorable walking trail right on the Cahaba River. Recently some ducks and a blue heron have made their home in the wetlands section of the trail. A great local spot to get some exercise and enjoy some of the beauty Alabama has to offer.

name: Scott Cole
text:
What great little trail. Really nice way to use land that would not be usable for any other purpose.

Hope it stays a secret.

name: john holmes
text: One of these walking parks in the greater Birmingham area.. well done.

name: Tammy Howell
text: Absolutely beautiful place great to get the dogs out

name: Ben Doerner
text: Nice little walk, well kept..

name: Gary Grimes
text: An unknown treasure

name: Jesse Alley
text: Trails are great. Well maintained and well marked, but the this trailhead was completely non-obvious. Drove by it twice before I realized where I needed to park. It's just the parking lot for the baseball field across the street. Could use better signage

name: r callie1
text: Great trail!

name: Jake Siler
text: I absolutely love ruffner mountain. Parking at the ballfields is a nice change up from the trail head entrance.  The hike to the over look is cut in half atleaat and it's just a way easier hike. Be ready to pay the 4 dollar parking for the whole day but it's worth it for the upkeep of the trails.

name: Austin Hosier
text: Great for trail crawling for RCs an walking

name: Gottfried Kibelka
text: A convenient access point to explore the trails and sights of Ruffner Mountain with plenty of parking across the street at Ruffner Baseball field.  The trail head is access point to the Ridge and Valley trail that connects on both ends to the Quarry trail for a nice loop hike. Walking straight north from the trail head it is only a short hike (15 min, 0.6 miles, 250 feet gain in elevation) to one of the best vista points in the Birmingham area, Hawk's view. Hiking north east will bring you to the ore crusher #3 and the nature center. Don't underestimated a quick loop to the crusher, although only 2.7 miles but you will experience 1200 ft of change in elevation.

name: Tom Mclemore
text: Great hiking and a hidden gem in Irondale

name: Miles Maheu
text: Epic

name: Helen Schneider
text: Goggle Maps did not start me in the right place. There is a parking lot up by the Vulcan statue. It would be easier to start there. Nice paved trail not steep.

name: Tina Willman-Hammar
text:
I “walked” this trail yesterday, and found it an excellent way to walk a few miles “in town.” I stayed at the Doubletree and noticed that no one put mileages on any of these comments. So, here’s some info.  I did a just over 4 mi loop. Doubletree to Trail, walking up 20th St S, is about one mile, mostly uphill. (Don’t follow google’s directions to the Vulcan man, if you want to see him too, because there’s some insanity to it - it’s a shorter walk, and the parking lot is before the “hook.”)  This walk will lose the sidewalk on 20th for a bit but it’s just a short stretch.
It’s about one mile from the start of the trail to the junction of 11th Pl S. (Hard right turn, downhill - you can’t miss it.) You could probably shorten this up a tad if you go down the steps through the apartment complex below.
Then, it’s about 2 miles back. I walked downhill 11th Pl S to where I walked around a business to 10th Ave S past the campus. There’s a ton of construction on campus right now but you can walk through.
Overall, very pleasant. The trail is mostly shaded, with good views. I came across runners and cyclists, but not many. It’s quiet on a weekday morning.  Birmingham has lots of good places to wander. I’d recommend this.

name: Davey “DJ” Johnson
text: Great walking spot that goes on for about 4 to 5 miles.

name: Thornton Sargent
text: Best viewing point of the city while having a day walk

name: Seyedmostafa Jafarzadehfadaki
text: Amazing place

name: Jessica Meuse
text: Beautiful trail with great views of the city. Long enough to actually go on a jog, or you can walk the whole thing. Lots of people bring dogs!

name: Michael Shelby
text: Nice walk and great view.

name: Shannon Carden
text: This trail is an easy walk with city views. Lots of people on bikes and people with dogs walk this. There is a sizable homeless tent village just off this trail that you may hear from.

name: Seyedmostafa Jafarzadehfadaki
text: Amazing place

name: Gottfried Kibelka
text: Don't expect too much nature here. The trail is in an urban area and pretty straight and boring. The trail offers great views over Birmingham and interesting views into the backyards of some houses close to the trail. Not much parking on either end (Vulcan or 11th Place S)

name: Zac Smith
text: its a short cut to work for me. and i found $5 so 5 stars for me.

name: Robert Evans
text: Great views along the trail.  We took lots of great photos.  Worth at least one visit in each season to see all the changes each season brings.

name: Caleb Wilson
text: It’s nice but not amazing

name: nafiul islam
text: Love the view of the downtown!

name: Ryan Linkous
text: Definitely a great trail to take run or walk on. It has a great view. However, it could use better and more accessible parking. It’d be cool if it ran from Green Springs/6th Ave S all the way to Richard Arrington/21st.

name: Stephen Buchanan
text: Level walking end to end, Vulcan to Greensprings. Great!

name: Mr JustPassin
text:
Great place.
People are kind of meh

name: Stephanie Pilgrim Moore
text: Nice views of Birmingham.

name: Don Sheafor
text: Awesome place to visit

name: G A
text: Some of the best views of Birmingham!

name: hilary schulak
text: Nice place for a walk

name: Tim Lynch
text: See the city as you walk.

name: SeantheSwede
text: New trails are legit.

name: Steven Morgan
text: Awesome

name: Lisa Neukam
text: Ok

name: J.A. T
text: Good

name: hiromi nagano
text:
(Translated by Google) The scenery in the evening is beautiful.

(Original)
夕方の景色は綺麗です❗

name: jonathan dryer
text: This place is definitely a hidden gem. Wow!!! It a difficult hike down hill and up hill but this waterfall was amazing the multiple waterfall after a good rain I can imagine are super amazing coming off the canyon walls. The water coming out of the rock that makes the waterfall is super cool if you can get up close to it on a dry spell it's doable. It is a true 6.8 miles round trip the hike back is what is the hardest. Follow the red trail when you get to the valley follow the second creek to waterfall Clark Cemetery

name: Dylan Woessner
text: This was a long trip. Took about 5 hours from start to finish. Well worth the work though. Lots of great scenery to view and the end point is a great destination.

name: Rick Cooper
text: Awesome! Well worth the long hike. Plan on spending the entire day. The hike back is all uphill.

name: The Bearded Man-Drenaline
text: Was an epic Hike-a-bike! Obviously I couldn't bike all of it, that's where the hike comes in, some of the best views these eyes have seen. The difficulty level depends on the state of your health and fitness, as a healthy 35 year old, I would call it moderate, well worth it, next time I wont bring the bike but it was worth the challenge! Always a blessing to be able to enjoy YHWH's beautiful creation🙌

name: Bartholomew Roland
text:
This is a stunningly beautiful trail that ends with a waterfall tucked behind a golden amphitheater of stone.

The trail is a difficult hike. You will go nearly 1,300ft down and back up the ravine. The trail can be nearly 6-7 miles in length if you push all the way to the back of the gorge (out + back). There are also plenty of places to step off the trail and do some exploring. The stoney riverbanks were a ton of fun to pick around and added some extra joy and length to our trip.

The trailhead here has two handicap accessible portable toilets for those in need, and the gravel parking lot is right off a paved road. There are no trash receptacles, you'll need to pack out. This trail is easy to get to from the highway.

name: Lyndsay MacPhee
text: This is a beautiful place! It took us about 4 hours to hike. The trail is well marked with red blazes on trees about every 10 feet or so. If you are hiking at dusk or at night, be sure to look for them closely on the switchback portion of the trail. There are two log bridges to cross, currently being replaced with sturdier concrete and steel bridges. The trail is very steep at points and is also pretty narrow. Make sure to bring plenty of water!! The horseback riding trail crosses the foot hiker trail twice. Once you cross the second bridge, you can choose to go along the top of the Walls of Jericho or go into the Walls of Jericho. My group opted to go into the Walls. It is definitely worth the hike!! It's very awe inspiring to be inside. Make sure to enjoy it while you're there!! This is a great day hike!!

name: Michael Turner
text: Excellent Trail! Be warned though, it is not for the meek. Definitely no strollers. I recommend taking a walking stick. It is approximately two hours to the waterfall from the Alabama parking area. (Dependant on how fast you walk) Follow the red paint on the trees, it is very clearly marked! There is no bathroom or water fountain at the waterfall, go prepared.

name: Tim Moore
text:
This place is definitely worth a visit. Plan for a whole day.  The relatively short distance is more than made up for by the steep elevation change.

If you do want to camp out, there are several designated campsites on the trail.

name: Tim Moore
text:
This place is definitely worth a visit. Plan for a whole day.  The relatively short distance is more than made up for by the steep elevation change.

If you do want to camp out, there are several designated campsites on the trail.

name: D Boyd
text: Walls of Jericho is one of my favorite places to hike in Alabama. My first trip was over 40 years ago. Each season provides something different. The large rock formation near the falls at the very north point is amazing. In many ways it is a very unique formation for this area. The hike out is a challenge and a good training exercise for even bigger hikes. This is one of those hikes where you should make an effort to be prepared. I have shared water with much younger hikers that thought they could hike in and back without water in July?! I recommend you make the side trip to see where Mill Creek (which you pass on the way to the Walls) originates from a hole in the rocks east of the trail.

name: Liz Rogers
text: I hiked here October 3, 2020 from the Alabama side, as part of a spiritual cleaning and as a reward to myself for loosing 130lbs. I had never been on a hike before in my life and I was a little scared, but I spent about a month getting physically and mentally prepared for it. I had done alot of research and studying the trail too. I also studied some on the Walls of Jericho story in the Bible which helped enhance my experience on the trail. It was a beautiful, religious and an amazing experience! However, this hike is not for the faint of heart and it is not your regular walk in the park. I highly recommend taking a hiking stick, being physically and mentally prepared and wearing comfortable clothes and hiking shoes or boots. It took me about 8 hours to hike roundtrip, of course I took my time since I wasn't used to the trail and wanted to take in as much as I could. Bring plenty of snacks and water and a couple bottles of Powerade. After I completed the hike, I gave up my right to never complain about anything ever again and include more gratitude in my life. This hike was also a teacher in a way. I will definitely do it again!

name: Darren Scott
text: 3.5 miles and you will need to cross ankle deep water to get to the bigger falls. Beautiful!!

name: Dennis Dickson
text: Nice hike, I wish the signs had direction arrows on them.

name: Wil Bowman
text: Best hike in Alabama, hands down. Traveling light, an experienced hiker should be able to make the round trip in 3 hours. The first three miles are also really good for trail running. It can get crowded, so you have to hit it early in the busy season.

name: Eric Cameron
text: Beautiful hike! Start early!!

name: Howard Smithey, Sr
text: Awesome! A 'must-do' for the avid hiker.

name: Rob Easter
text: Moderate hike: All down hill going to the Walls but all uphill coming back so be prepared for that.

name: Karol Gawrych
text: The walls of Jericho hike is designated as difficult, but my wife and I found it to be moderate at best. It is log, taking about 3 hours round trip and has a long uphill climb on the return trip, but it is a gradual ascent. Nothing a little patience and will power cannot overcome! The views and tranquility are well worth the effort.

name: Rob Daugherty
text: It's worth the long walk.  The return walk of 2 miles mostly UPHILL can be difficult. Give yourself extra time for slower return.  ALSO... Be warned, the South Rim trail does NOT circle around to the beautiful end like the trailhead map shows.  You have sort of a view through the trees (no, it isn't worth the hike) but then you come to a red blazed END.  I tried hiking further as there is a slight trail, but it soon just turns into nothing.  You can bravely trudge through the forest (surely coming to a cliff face) or turn around and walk the plus-mile back.  Stay to your right when you see the South Rim sign.  It's beautiful and I didn't want to leave.

name: Chris Lett
text:
This is a place of sanctuary. A long rewarding walk.  This trail is down hill on the way to the water hole. On the way back you are going up hill so make sure you are prepared.

My dog and I hiked this trail during mid July and It was miserably hot with no wind chill so getting to the water hole was very rewarding. If you hike trail first thing in the morning you will make it to the trail by the evening. So if you plan on hitting the water hole before the sun sets make sure you start early.

If you use a Garmin GPS there are a few check points and marked points for sites of interest (You're Welcome).

The trail was a bit confusing at some points due to missing signs.  Good ole American flags someone else planted before me helped guide the way during confusing intersecting points. I took note of this for future hikes and I will always carry markers with me and for others in the future.

I hope to hike this trail in the Fall one day so I can see all the creeks filled with water instead of a dried up creeks... Overall 5 star from me and my furry friend.

name: Nancy Forshaw
text: Beautiful place and pleasant hike down. Going back up is VERY strenuous. It's a 1,000 feet elevation from the top of the trailhead down to the creek.

name: Holly Owens
text: Absolutely beautiful!! Longest hike I've been on but definitely worth it!

name: Dennis Dickson
text: Nice hike, I wish the signs had direction arrows on them.

name: Karol Gawrych
text: The walls of Jericho hike is designated as difficult, but my wife and I found it to be moderate at best. It is log, taking about 3 hours round trip and has a long uphill climb on the return trip, but it is a gradual ascent. Nothing a little patience and will power cannot overcome! The views and tranquility are well worth the effort.

name: Wil Bowman
text: Best hike in Alabama, hands down. Traveling light, an experienced hiker should be able to make the round trip in 3 hours. The first three miles are also really good for trail running. It can get crowded, so you have to hit it early in the busy season.

name: Olivia Buchanan
text: Amazing hike, but definitely strenuous. It's downhill going in so that's pretty easy, but it's all uphill on the way back out which is where it gets exhausting. We got a little lost so make sure you cross 2 tree bridges and take the path by the barbed wire which will lead you along a steep rocky hillside. The sight of the water pool waiting for you at the end is breathtaking!

name: Howard Smithey, Sr
text: Awesome! A 'must-do' for the avid hiker.

name: Ryan Fogg
text:
Its going to take the average hiker 2.5 - 3 hours to get in +30 minutes at the falls to explore, then another 2.5 - 3 hours back out.
Cliff notes:
Extremely wet and slippery in spots especially after recent rain
Bring water shoes for falls area
Plenty of water (at least 2L/person) and food
Poison ivy is EVERYWHERE along the trails (miles of it) be extremely vigilant if allergic
Lots of giant millipedes (Apheloria virginiensis corrugate)
AL trailhead is red, horse trail is white. They will cross each other frequently, pay attention to the marks.  Watch out around the campground area and don't accidentally go on the South Rim Trail, stay near the barbed wire/pink flagged trees which is the trail.

name: Justin Lacey
text: A good long hike, the switch backs help out a lot though. Hiked with a 5&6 year old and they did great but we walk hills pretty often.  Beautiful place, I do wish people would pick up after themselves better though. I'll probably check it out again in the fall

name: Matthew Sims
text: Beautiful place! We loved taking our hammocks and camping out for a few days. Worth the hike and climb to see the fall.

name: Nancy Forshaw
text: Beautiful place and pleasant hike down. Going back up is VERY strenuous. It's a 1,000 feet elevation from the top of the trailhead down to the creek.

name: Wallace Kistler
text: Great hike - popular place!

name: Ella White
text: Awesome place for hiking with the whole family

name: Rob Daugherty
text: It's worth the long walk.  The return walk of 2 miles mostly UPHILL can be difficult. Give yourself extra time for slower return.  ALSO... Be warned, the South Rim trail does NOT circle around to the beautiful end like the trailhead map shows.  You have sort of a view through the trees (no, it isn't worth the hike) but then you come to a red blazed END.  I tried hiking further as there is a slight trail, but it soon just turns into nothing.  You can bravely trudge through the forest (surely coming to a cliff face) or turn around and walk the plus-mile back.  Stay to your right when you see the South Rim sign.  It's beautiful and I didn't want to leave.

name: Ryan Fogg
text:
Its going to take the average hiker 2.5 - 3 hours to get in +30 minutes at the falls to explore, then another 2.5 - 3 hours back out.
Cliff notes:
Extremely wet and slippery in spots especially after recent rain
Bring water shoes for falls area
Plenty of water (at least 2L/person) and food
Poison ivy is EVERYWHERE along the trails (miles of it) be extremely vigilant if allergic
Lots of giant millipedes (Apheloria virginiensis corrugate)
AL trailhead is red, horse trail is white. They will cross each other frequently, pay attention to the marks.  Watch out around the campground area and don't accidentally go on the South Rim Trail, stay near the barbed wire/pink flagged trees which is the trail.

name: John Beckett
text: This is an awesome hike! There are details elsewhere, I won't get into them here.

name: Jasper Montgomery
text: This is such an amazing place to hike! With beautiful scenery

name: David Molvik
text: Great place to hike. This hike gets the heart pumping.

name: Holly Owens
text: Absolutely beautiful!! Longest hike I've been on but definitely worth it!

name: Vacations Alabama
text: Such a beautiful trail.

name: Nathon Roden
text: This is a local spot for me. I've hiked it at night and day. The second waterfall is crazy cool. But of a rough one. Carry water.

name: Alex K
text: Be prepared for a hike!! Lots of legwork to get to the falls, but definitely worth it. This trail is rated hard by alltrails, rei, and other places. Do your research and pack accordingly. But I had a magical day down at the water.

name: William Sciaroni
text: As experienced hikers, we hiked there and back just under 3-hours. With an hour to explore, our overall trip took 4 hours. We were in good shape, so these are not going to be typical times.  Do not attempt this without Plenty of water. We each consumed about 3 Liters.  If you are inexperienced or not in top shape, I would say this hike could take you 5-6 hours round trip. Be prepared and stay safe.

name: Peter McCoy
text: Great hike.  Took about 4 hours with plenty of time to enjoy the falls.  The hike out may be difficult for young children or people that aren't in shape.  Plan for 5-6 hours if you think you may need multiple rest breaks.  It's not Niagra falls but it is impressive when there is a lot of water flowing.  It is especially interesting how the river has disappears into the canyon wall at the base of the falls to reemerge downstream.  Great thing about the trail is that there are plenty of things to see other than the falls.

name: Heath Varmette
text: The water hole is amazing

name: Andrew Rodriguez
text: A somewhat strenuous hike, but a serene payoff.

name: Jacob Mcdaniel
text: Beautiful area for hiking and photography. Long trail but was worth it.

name: Bobby Walton
text: Awesome place 😊

name: Marc Compton
text: It is great place to hike that pushes your limits and great sites to see throughout the entire hike.

name: MicusIII
text: A super beautiful and amazing trail. I would recommend it to everyone!

name: Chris
text: Neat trail

name: Stephen Glass
text: Awesome waterfall!

name: Steven Hughes
text: Awesome place. Highly recommend.

name: Richard York
text: It was a nice hike..

name: Bethany Hart
text: Definitely a difficult hike but if you prepare mentally and bring plenty of water it's beyond rewarding!!

name: Mr. Hyde
text:
The hike back up from the waterfall to the parking lot was an hour and a half.

Gorgeous colors with the sunlight
You will have to take your shoes off or else they will get wet. There is ankle deep water that is almost impossible to go around.

name: Jaky Suarez
text: Whatever you do!!!! If you are walking do not take the horse trail also if you’re coming from the Scottsboro side please do not make the mistake my group and I did do get off in the first Parking lot, my group and I got lost and even almost got bitten by a rattle snake. And to top it off we did not find the waterfall and walked 7 hours being lost. It is Very easy to veer off the trail so please pay attention!!

name: Tammy McKendree
text: Nice place to walk nature trails. They also have horse trails. It's free to visit here. The older lady at the desk was very helpful and nice.

name: Justine Vild
text: If you need some really good exercise and are in relatively good shape, do this hike. It took us about 3h15 total with some very brief stops along the way and about a 15 min break enjoying the "walls". We were moving though. You will need at least 3 water bottles per person during the hot summer months. More if you drink a lot while you hike. Pay attention to the red markers because there are a few confusing spots. You hike down with a steep hike up at the end to get to the "walls" which is a small waterfall/roccky stream area. The way back up can be brutal. I haven't done this in a year or two and I was hoping the end was just up the next hill but then there were 7 more hills after every last hill. Lol Great, challenging hike though. After I forget how hard it was, I'll do it again. 😉

name: Christy Isbell
text: Very long and I would rate moderate to difficult trail that winds down a mountain side. Plan to walk 4plus hours. Take plenty of water/ a lunch and snacks. I do not recommend this trail for small children.

name: Flooding Rivers
text: OMG!!!!! Not for the novice.  We took a group of 8, 4 children (8-12) and 4 adults. We started out way too late and it took 6 hours instead of the 4 we estimated.  2 hours in the pitch black during a MONSOON (which came out of nowhere with no warning) was nothing short of TERRORIZING!!  Fortunately we all lived, but rivers come out of nowhere when the rain falls.  Steep cliffs, very rocky.  A day and night we won't soon forget!  The only thing missing was bigfoot!

name: Jason Sides
text:
Love this place but not for the faint at heart or someone that's not physically fit to walk a distance.
The trails can be quite demanding but definitely worth the hike if you can handle it.
Great for younger folks who love nature

name: Joe Schmoe
text:
Easy then tough then tougher.
Turn around
Real tough, easier then real tough to finish.

name: Mahnorreah ChinHun
text: Strenuous hiking trail. Make sure to walk on the pathway. Some kids got lost when we were there,  and one kid broke his ankle while trying to cut through.  Going downward was okay but hiking back up, oh man! I had fun and enjoyed it.

name: Cameron Nickle
text: Great trail. Beautiful site at the bottom. Took my dog and I about 3 hours round trip. But be warned you're going down hill when you start out and up hill on your way back to the parking lot. It's a lot easier to to the falls than it is coming back.

name: Thom Wells
text: Beautiful hike.   Lovely forest

name: Jackson Buckner
text: Bring food, and plenty of water, because once you get to the spring at the walls itll be hard to want to leave. Bring what you need to stay as long as you can.

name: Jennifer Cruz
text: Amazing place but it's a very very difficult hike bring lots of snack and water and pack lightly expect to hike for at least 6 -7 hours with a almost 8 mile long round trip to the hike

name: Brandon Saltzmann
text: When the state says its gonna take you at least 6 hours to hike this. Please don't go 2 hours before nightfall. I did and we had to walk a random road for 2.4 miles. At one point we had been followed by some animals in the woods. The hike was awesome though as were always looking for the thrill. We went swimming too and it was freezing cold. I recommend taking a lot of water and maybe a snack or two. But my brothers and I are adventurous so we had nothing but our clothes and shoes. 5 stars definitely will be going back. This hike was just amazing!!

name: Marty Couey
text: Great scenery, well marked trail, excellent exercise.  The walk back out is taxing. Give yourself time if you aren't in great shape.

name: Steve Parsons
text: Advise-go prepared. We did this hike on a whim and got educated. The hike took us longer than expected and we had to almost race back up the mountain before it got dark. Will go back again when more time.

name: Patricia Kerins
text: This is definitely NOT  a beginner trail! However  it is AWESOME!! Worth the hike for sure!

name: Chris Davis
text: Great hike! Camped at the camp site at the bottom, best solo camp site so far. Wonderful having the whole place to myself,  hiked to the falls the next day. Falls wasn't running but still awesome with the spring flowing out. I climbed up to the walls of Jericho falls and I can imagine its beautiful with some water but definitely would add to the danger of get there.The climb by out was a pretty long climb but definitely worth it all. Be careful in the off season coming by, It was easy to get turned around when u crossing over the horse trail. Give yourself time for the climb out, take alot of breaks and you got this. Pack in, pack out!

name: Gottfried Kibelka
text:
Please don't underestimate the 1000 feet gain in elevation over the last 2 miles of the hike.  I've done the hike in summer at 90 F  and just the other day at 40 F. I do prefer winter time. With no leaves you have a much better view and the hike back and up to the trailhead is so much easier when it's not as hot. In summer 2 L of water was not enough for me, in winter I only drank 0.5 L.
Go after rain, the creeks and waterfalls are much more impressive. Bring a walking stick, the trail can be very slick after rain. Bring water shoes if you want to safely cross the creek at the waterfall and you might want to bring a hammock to relax in the trees close to the waterfall.
Most importantly: Leave no trace!! Campers don't always see the need to pack their trash out and I am highly annoyed when I see slightly burned cans in a fire ring. I can get pretty mad when people believe that they must chop down a living tree because they didn't collect enough dead wood before they started a fire. Freshly cut trees will smoke but not burn (unless you have a strong fire anyways). Since I am on my soapbox:  Wear waterproof boots and step into puddles on the trail. Walking around the puddle only widens the trail and increases the muddy area.

name: John Buckelew
text: Absolutely beautiful. The 4 mile hike down 1000 ft to the Walls are worth the pain of the 4 mile hike up 1000 ft.

name: Joseph Drury
text: Definitely not a hike for those who cant walk for ling periods. Gorgeous landscape near the water.

name: Chris Reid
text: Very nice trailhead for backpackers. There is a Porta-potty in the parking lot, and there is a basic Campground a few hundred meters from the lot. The trail is well marked, and it is about 4 miles to the falls. The hills are somewhat steep, so be prepared and bring water.

name: Paula Stewart
text: Great hike! Need to be really prepared for hike and take plenty of water. Tough hike

name: Mary T
text: This is a really beautiful place. Took 4 kids ages 9-14 and did it in a little over 5 hours including an hour to play and picnic at the falls. Would not consider it a “hard” trail if you’ve done much hiking outside of AL. But pretty sure it is more than 6 miles. Had such a great time and Wish we had planned a longer day or overnight. Red blazes were not very evident the last half mile or so but it’s just one trail and stays along the water at the end.   Be sure to go all the way to the end, across and up past the first falls.

name: Amanda Foster
text: My oh my was it a hot day. But great hike with a nice cold pool at the bottom

name: Scotty Tucker
text: Very difficult hike to the Walls of Jerricho but it is very rewarding.  It is a 6.6 mile round trip hike to the waterfall. There is port a potties at the parking lot. There is tent camping at the parking lot.

name: Sharon Kilzer
text: Wonderful trail, great swimming hole

name: Jennifer Thomas
text: Beautiful hike but not for the faint of heart.  Very difficult hike and must be cautious after it has rained cause it is very slippery.

name: Satish Vedula
text: Definitely one of the toughest hikes! Took around 4 hrs to go to the Wall and back.Waterfalls was so beautiful. Make sure you carry enough water as the return journey from the falls is gonna be rough!

name: Nikolai Claud
text: Awesome hike. The hike out was super strenuous, but we decided to just walk straight up the hills instead of taking the trail. We went when the water was up, and it was really cool. I need to go back.

name: phyllis larson
text: Challenging

name: C W
text: A hike for the experienced, and well worth it. Leave nothing but footprints, take nothing but memories!

name: Bryan Tauchen
text: Pretty trail with great waterfall at end. Out and back, not much loop option. Remember that you start by dropping about 700 ft. You need to climb that 700 feet.

name: Leland Campbell
text: great trail, best afew days a after good rain to get the water level up. if you're not an experienced hiker allow at least 6 hours

name: Amy Dubois
text: A difficult hike but it was beautiful!

name: Melissa Marsh
text: Gorgeous destination. Easy hike in, but all uphill on the way back. Several interesting sights on the trail. Saw a good many fellow hikers, which can be good or bad depending on how you feel about such.

name: Rotten Candy
text: So much fun! Alot of hard walking but worth it. Even my 5 year old finished it and back

name: Kristi Tahada
text:
If you're not in shape, like me, this trail will take everything you have and then some. Going down is challenging but well worth it to see the walls, the little waterfalls, and the caverns. The water was really cold but we got in anyway. Coming back up? BRUTAL! I cried, I screamed, got debilitating leg cramps. Did I mention it's brutal?

Be sure to wear covering clothes because the trail is very narrow in places and you will be brushing up against foliage (some of which has thorns), climbing over and under fallen trees, and navigating mud pits. Take plenty of water and food. Stretch. Write your will. Have fun lol

name: Ellen George
text: Make sure you come prepared!!!! This is a difficult hike so bring adequate food and water. The last two miles back to your car are straight uphill and it is extremely boring. Also I recommend going after a heavy rain. When we went there wasnt much of a waterfall at the end.

name: Tanner Godfrey
text: Fun trail and beautiful destination. The cascades and falls in the canyon are amazing and definitely worth the hike. Note of caution: come prepared (water, fitness, good shoes, etc.) It's an easy hike down but three miles up-hill going out. We saw several people really struggling coming out. Also careful on the falls. We saw two people slip and go over the drop (10 feet); luckily they missed the shallow rock shelf.

name: Robert Flowers
text: This was an excellent hike today. I highly recommend hiking at this beautiful place. It is a strenuous hike,  it is best to leave plenty of time for the adventure.

name: alex davis
text: Grew up in these woods, cultivated the land in these woods, better have strong legs to make this trip it is no joke you hike down a mountain, and up a creek bed, is the best way to hike this. Best time to go is a few days after a good rain when the water is still flowing out of the mountain. Nice swimming hole to cool you off, extremely cold and clear water. Have at least a gallon of water per person(for the trip in) another gallon for the trip out. Very old cemetery in the valley before the ascent to the walls along with a primitive campground for tents and small campfires. The hurricane creek is teeming with different aquatic life if you venture down the creek with a fishing pole you can catch some of the best tasting fish you've ever eaten. Again this isn't a beginners trail and there are plenty of wildlife in those woods, snakes included. After your endeavor to the walls is complete the hike out is up the mountain so be prepared to get winded. Worth the hike, worth the workout, take it from someone who has been in those woods for 20 years. Good luck

name: Ty Reed
text: Always a beautiful hike, no matter what time of year you visit.

name: Melody 123
text: BRING LOTS OF WATER AND ELECTROLYTE DRINKS VERY HARD HIKE BUT BEAUTIFUL SWIM HOLE AT THE BOTTOM

name: Tony Alexander
text: Beautiful. And good exercise.

name: Bill P.
text: Best hike ever....I dont know what some of you whiners are complaining about. This trail is not that difficult, compared to many out west. Put your big boy and girl panties on and enjoy the beauty. Several people who appeared to be handicapped handled the trail just fine. It was 7 miles round trip, but it was far from difficult compared to some we have done. It also helps if you bring a bottle of wine or your favorite adult beverage to enjoy at the pool at the bottom.

name: Jed Park
text: Great experience.  Everyone who can go (it's an 8 mile hike with significant elevation changes) should go.

name: Gary Moore
text: Great place to go. Went for my son's 27th birthday. Grulling 6 hours, but great. Saw people starting their decent at 3:00. Hope they got out before dark. Did I say it was great? Where are my Epsom salts?

name: Chip Ferrell
text: Pretty cool place. Went in from Alabama trail head. Hiked straight  down for 3 miles. The Walls are really cool to check out. The 3 mile hike out is the same trail going up. Take what you need and leave the cry babies at home. Overall I had 8 miles on the nose when I finished. I recommend carrying a water bottle.

name: Scott Staton
text: Absolutely a beautiful place carved into the hills. The hike in and out is a bear because the depth of the canyon. The trail is in excellent shape, just a lot of it.

name: Seth Allison
text: Decent graveled parking lot with space for ~25 cars.

name: Chris Fears
text: 1st parking lot, coming from Woodville is for horseback riding trail, 1 mile torwards TN is foot trailhead.

name: Wayne
text: This is not an easy or well marked trail.  But it's beautiful.  Six mile hike (round trip), 1500 elevation change.

name: Dan Anderson
text: Great, but strenuous hike.  Excellent for both day hikes and overnight backpacking camp.  Bring at least 2qts of water (or a filter)

name: W3 S33 33
text: This trail is NOT for the faint of heart, but it is beautiful!  Take a friend or twi,

name: Chuck Bryant
text: Tough trail but raining and muddy, hell. It will test you. Go try it.

name: Dustin Walker
text: Loved it. Wasn't a very hard hike but challenging.

name: Colleen Costigan
text: Hard trail but very fun. Would be good for packing

name: Hunter Henson
text: Wonderful, Beautiful place. Nice place to get away for a few hours and experience the wilderness.

name: Justin Loyd
text: Great hiking spot in North Alabama, right on the Alabama Tennessee border. Very cool trail that is challenging and fun.

name: Nicky Beale
text: A very pretty but challenging hike. Make sure to bring snacks and water.

name: Michael Willis
text: It's longer than 3 miles, but beautiful.

name: rico hartman
text: Am amazing place.

name: Tamyeria Dickson
text: According to the website this is a 6.7 mike hike which is very incorrect. We took our 3 daughters ages 14 to 23. When I got to the bottom I collapsed and we were told it would take 5-10 hours for help to arrive by horseback. On that way back everyone was so scared and nervous. We hike. We’re not rookies at this. We’ve done many things that are considered a difficult hike. This was by far the most dangerous hike we’ve ever been on. Rattle snakes everywhere and just a terrible path with loads of dangerous things and accidents waiting to happen.

name: tim lowe
text: It was hell...very unforgiving.  I will never forget this day.

name: Jeanie Collins
text: Great hike!

name: Nathan Allen
text: A great place for a day hike. There is a also nice place to take a dip mid way through the hike. If you can arrange it, hiking from the Tennessee trailhead to the Alabama Trailhead is a good way to see the area, you will need two vehicles to drop one off at the destination trailhead.

name: Jesse Smith
text: Beautiful hike and worth the effort to get back up the hill!

name: David Lindsey
text: Awesome trail, the waterfall almost isn't worth the 3 mile hike. But the scenery on the way there was great.

name: jennyferfaithhope
text:
We walked two miles in and never found the river  :(  Bring a trail map.
Quite beautiful.

name: Edward Jimenez
text: Great hike! Great camping sites.

name: Jason Agee
text: Great hike have been here twice first trip done an overnight second trip spent 2 nights will be back again

name: William Evans
text: we went on Alabama side it's a good thing to do but make sure you have water and in good shape

name: Joe Parks
text: Walls are amazing, thou it was really crowded for backpacking on an weekend in November

name: Candi Bickers
text: Fun and beautiful. Much more difficult hike than you will expect.

name: Johanna Stevens
text: Very difficult hike after about the first mile.

name: J B
text: Cool trail, very long. Need the whole day off to hike.

name: madelyn breeding
text: such a beautiful place to be. it may be a tough hike going back up but the end view is so worth it!

name: Mik S
text:
Great public land access
Land trust needs to add some latrines at bottom and have trash pickup in campground area

name: Justin Quinn
text: Very nice hike, great views. Make sure to take plenty of water and snacks.

name: LaJarvis Provins
text: Nice hike!!

name: Teresa Baldwin
text: Long trails love it.

name: Kayla Underwood
text: Long hike

name: Tommy Lee
text: Great day hike.

name: Melissa Dutton
text: This is one of my go to places to hike becuse its so close to home

name: MLChampion
text: Hard hike but worth it

name: Jaeryong Park
text: No water in creek and falls

name: John Beckett
text: I've already done this.

name: Robert Whiddon
text: Be prepared

name: Randy Hamilton
text: Long trail.

name: Ben Nelson
text: Fantastic hike.

name: Charles Batchelor
text: Awsome during the winter months

name: Gypsy Wind
text:
(Translated by Google) Great hikei go often

(Original)
Great hikei go often

name: Brian Woods
text: Lots of hog sign

name: David Shockey
text: The route from Braziel TH stop the Big Tree is not the shortest but it is the easiest. Be sure to allow enough time to get back out if you are making a day trip. There is no easily accessible water along the route so pack accordingly.

name: Lynn Wray Dillard (Alabama Creeks)
text: Huge parking area, made special for horse trailers. Watch your step!

name: That One Dude
text: Really good trails! Beautiful views. A good workout for the legs and pet friendly, so that's a bonus. We took our cats on a walk and they loved it!

name: Ben Whitson
text: Fantastic hiking spot with plenty of parking. Some friends and I spent 4 days 3 nights hiking around and camping. The south side is beautiful and a fairly easy hike. It has nice views of some water feature too. The north side starts with a bit of a climb and water isn't found for a while unless you hike down a very steep section off trail. All in all a fantastic place to spend either the day or a whole weekend.

name: Mollie Waters
text: Plentybof parking, but you'll have to share it with the hunters during hunting season. They are always nice, though.

name: Jeff Buckingham
text: Dugger Mountain, Great place to hike, moderate challenge

name: Jason Jackson
text: Gateway to the Dugger wilderness.   A great spot for a southbound hike yo Choccoloco lake or north into the Dugger wilderness.

name: beverly hamilton
text: One of my favorite things to do is hike! This place is a great hiking trail! Beautiful Land!

name: Ferrell Moultrie
text: Easy access from paved road. Lots of parking.

name: Reaper Crew
text: Beautiful place to go home or just sit by the creek

name: Pearl D
text: Lots of hiking trails on the Pinhoti Trail. Moderate to strenious trails.

name: Robyn Rosenwald
text: This is a beautiful hike through forest, with several stream crossings that are easy to navigate during the summer months. It is uphill, but mostly not steep for the first couple of miles. Then it gets steeper and more challenging. If you hike this trail to its end you intersect the Lobo peak trail, but it is very difficult to hike this trail all the way to Lobo peak. Because it is on the way to Taos Ski Valley and at higher elevation that Taos, it is a great choice for a hot day. It is about 10-15 degrees cooler than in Taos here.

name: G Felix
text: Amazing

name: Joe E Montano
text: Took a walk pick some wild oregano!

name: MashuMichelle “Mashu2You” Hart
text: Can't beat the beauty

name: Emily Johnson
text:
We arrived at the shelter about 6 p.m. after hiking all day.
Someone had left a chair, which is like heaven when you spend a few days sitting on just the ground. They had also left some firewood, which was much appreciated.
Sleeping in the shelter was the best nights sleep i have ever had in the woods. Would totally recommend utilizing it.

name: Odell Sanders
text: Forest Service replaced the old asphalt composite shingle roof and plywood that was leaking with a new galvanized metal roof.

name: Lamarian Jolley
text: Great camping location, with access by way of the Pinhoti Trail. Park at as many as 3 locations to hike in. 3 to 5 mile trails.

name: Amanda Mitchell
text: Amazing 🖤

name: Xander Bradfield
text: nature

name: Joseph Naramore
text: First time visitor and I love this place

name: David White
text: This hike is great! Not for little kids.

name: Gottfried Kibelka
text: Hiking up the orange trail you will find this spectacular (depends on rainfall) waterfall. I can sit, stare at the waterfall and pretend to be somewhere in the Sipsey.
